text: deep research is one of those popular
agent applications and a lot of the deep
research involves some kind of planning
step up front where you gather feedback
from the user and then you have some
kind of handoff process to a research
phase that does all the area of deep
research I built a little example of
this from scratch and we can walk
through it right now and show how you
can build a multi- aent system that
incorporates planning and research in
this way So just as an example I hooked
this up with some Langraph documentation
I can ask a question about Langraph and
it goes to this planner agent which is
going to do some upfront planning You
can see it's iteratively calling tools
and it did a bit of background research
very quickly and asks me some follow-up
questions and I can address the followup
questions So planner now has a better
sense for the scope of work and we get
this handoff mechanism to the researcher
The researcher kicks off its work and
the researcher returns us with the
implementation based upon our feedback
we provide the planner Now one of the
interesting things about deep research
applications you've seen for example
like open I deep research is that
there's a number of clarifying questions
that are asked up front when you give a
topic for research the agent returns
with which you then answer and in
conversation it finally decides it has
enough information to conduct research
and then research kicks off Now one way
to implement this is with a multi- aent
system So for example you could have an
agent that's a planner that's equipped
with some tools are relevant for more
high level planning and the planner
interacts with the user and clarifies
the scope as mentioned It then does a
handoff to a researcher agent which has
different tools in the case of deep
research For example the researcher may
have tools to search the web to read
pages visual tools to read images and so
forth And so this is a good example of
where a multi-agent architecture can
make a lot of sense Now one popular
multi- aent implementation that actually
was originally open source from OpenAI
is Swarm We have Langraph Swarm as our
own in-house implementation of this that
works with Langraph And there's a number
of other videos that I'll link to on
swarm in general But here's the overall
flow but here's kind of overall
schematic of the flow You can in this
case we have two different agents a
planner and a researcher and a handoff
mechanism that allows for handing off
between the two Now each of these agents
is just very simply a react agent
equipped with different tools necessary
for the particular research task that
they're given In the langraph swarm repo
we've added a folder of examples You can
see customer support You can see
research Here's just a very simple
research example which I walked through
already in studio We can look at the
notebook here You can specify the model
for conducting research You can define
handoff tools For example handoff tool
to transfer to the researcher agent or
handoff tool to transfer to the planner
agent Now as we saw in studio what's
going to happen is we're going to start
off with the planner The planner is
going to ask some follow-up questions to
the user And then when the planner is
satisfied it's going to go ahead and
perform a transfer using the swarm
handoff mechanism to the researcher And
really this is all the code necessary to
implement this So we use a langraph
pre-built to set up React agent We have
a planner and a researcher They both use
this simple fetch dock tool and they
have transfer tools to interact with one
another Now you can see as example
here's the planner prompt Here's a
researcher prompt And this is where you
can tell the agents how to perform this
task So in the planner prompt you
basically say reflect on the user's
input Use the fetch doc tool to read in
this case from an LM.ext file which
gives you access to Langraph
documentation After you read the
documentation ask for some clarifying
questions And when you have clear
project scope based on the user's
feedback select the most relevant docs
And then produce a short summary with
two sections a scope of work and a few
URLs to help with implementation And
that's it So that's really what the
planner does is responsible for
interacting with the user and laying out
the scope of work as well as the
relevant resources to accomplish the
task Now the researcher just will
reflect on the project scope it's given
and then it will go ahead and fetch all
the URLs that's been provided reflect on
them think carefully implement the
solution based on the user request and
if you need further clarification you
can go ahead and transfer back to the
planner for more kind of higher level
planning This is just one example of how
you can separate these two tasks Again
initialize two agents planner and
researcher And this is where we use our
swarm library Just create swarm pass in
your agents and you set planner as the
default Compile it In this case we're in
a notebook We compile with a
checkpointer That just allows us to
persist the state across a number of
different turns of conversation And
again let's just test this a second time
now in the notebook just to see it a
little bit differently We'll ask for the
application we just talked through And
let's look at the trace here and see
what the planner actually did So it
received the input from the user Right
Went ahead and called fetch doc with the
lm.ext we gave it So it grabs our
lm's.ext So it gives it an index of all
our documentation We can see here that
this was the tool call that responded
with all the docs and then it goes ahead
and reflects on the docs and asks some
follow-up questions Now we go ahead and
pass the feedback So what's pretty neat
is now we can see we passed our feedback
and we can actually look at all the
different model call So we can see our
planner initiates the model call to
transfer the research agent That
transfer occurs using our transfer
research agent handoff tool that's built
into Swarm Research agent receives a
system prompt as well as the full
context of the prior conversation It
goes ahead and starts fetching
documentation that was provided to it
from the planner We see the planner
gives us this nice scope of work Here's
what you should do Here's the URLs to
use Researcher says "Cool." It starts
fetching those URLs You can see those
tool calls all here Fetches additional
docs So it's gathering its sources and
it does the final implementation in this
last model call I went ahead and copied
that code over the notebook Let's
actually test to make sure it runs Here
it is
Cool And there it is So really the main
point here is that deep research is a
very good multi- aent application
because you can have a planning agent up
front as shown here that interacts with
the user that sets the scope of work and
then research agent or agents that have
tools that are more relevant for actual
search and that compile all the
information necessary to produce the
final report or final solution in this
case and we just showed a super simple
example of this idea performing research
over Langraph documentation to help
answer questions So hope this is a kind
of a useful overview of how you can use
swarm multi-agent architecture in these
types of planning research applications
and feel free to leave any comments or
questions below Tax
